fields.description:
After upgrading to 3.2.1,  loopback devices aren't being released by the SC (overlay) after upgrade to 3.2.1. This is causing users to hit the loopback limit under Linux.

The end result is that users are unable to attach volumes, its the [luck of the draw|http://idioms.thefreedictionary.com/luck+of+the+draw] whether they happen to be able to locate a free loopback device.

{code}

Could EUCA-4177 be related?

__ EDIT __ 

Edit with better summary.  So pre-upgrade the iscsivolumeinfo table contains volume list with information such as a loopback mapping (lodev_name) for the volume file.  After upgrade we don't do anything to these entries and so post-upgrade they continue to consume loopbacks, the SC doesn't do any cleaning here.  This means the user doesn't get the nice improvements in 3.2 in regards to only attaching a volume file to a loopback when the volume is in use.
fields.summary: Upgrade from 3.2.0 to 3.2.1 - SC fails to release loopback devices associated with unused volumes

comments.body:
Harold, yes, please update with SC logs. The CLC stuff is a red herring.

On Apr 11, 2013, at 6:57 AM, "Harold Spencer (JIRA)"

Also, in the eucalyptus_storage DB, there is a flag that tells you
whether clean up will occur for volumes that have been detached.
Please check that this flag is set to true for old volumes that have
been detached.
What is the flag supposed to be?
So we don't have anything in the "cleanup" column but we went ahead and removed the lodev_name entries and its cleaning up ...

[~neil],

In the eucalyptus_storage DB, the column is there, but this flag seems to not be working.  

Clean up is happening by the following script:

{code}for vol in $(cat all_volumes_id.txt); do psql -U root -d eucalyptus_storage -p 8777 -h /var/lib/eucalyptus/db/data -c "select lodev_name from iscsivolumeinfo where volume_name = '$vol'";done {code}

based on a list of all volumes which are in available state.

We stopped the SC, do the DB changes, then started the SC and clean up is happening.  

A few questions:

* When did this column get introduce into Eucalyptus (i.e. 3.2.0, 3.2.1, before)?

* What should the value of the flag be? 

* What is the expected behavior we expect based upon the value of the flag when the cloud is running?  When its restarted?  To be more clear, if this value is changed while the SC is running, what should happen?  If this value is changed with the SC is stopped, then started, what should happen?

* Does this flag only deal with overlay backend or does this affect other backends as well?

Can we also get confirmation of whether this cleanup was introduced in 3.2.1 or 3.2.2 and what EUCA ticket tracks that cleanup, just so we can track that.

Thanks
Whilst debugging this with the customer, we ran into EUCA-5699, cc [~neil]

[~neil], can you tell us if there is an issue that we know about that we can link to this ticket, and whether this has been fixed in 3.2.2 (per Darren's comment: https://eucalyptus.atlassian.net/browse/EUCA-5698?focusedCommentId=43138&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-43138)?
Loops also piling up in Eucalyptus 3.2.2 (upgraded from 3.2.1)
I removed the Benefit from this one so it will hit the next scrub.
@neil, can you comment on this?  We believe it is fixed in 3.3.0.

[~neil] to add info for a release note on the workaround for this.
All users of DAS or SANs are ok.  Overlay is affected for volumes created prior to 3.2.2 (even after upgrade to 3.2.2)

On upgrade from 3.2.0, the cleanup flag is not set for volumes that are not attached. The SC does not have knowledge of active attachments (it can possibly infer this, but we don't do that). The result is that existing volumes (from 3.2.0) won't be automatically unexported on a upgrade.

The workaround is to set the cleanup flag to true in eucalyptus_storage/Volumes after an upgrade (ONLY for volumes that are not attached).
What changes have been made in 3.3.0 to justify this as resolved?  Are we going to scrub and set the flag correctly in an upgrade from 3.2.X to 3.3.0 ?

The problem is that the SC does not have information in 3.2.x about whether a volume is attached. So we cannot set the cleanup flag to true for all old volumes, because we risk unexporting attached volumes.

In 3.3.0, this logic has changed substantially.

It is possible that if we require that all volumes are detached (stopped instances have all volumes detached by default even if it appears attached to the user), then we can clean the lodev_name field in the db and force re-attachment. However, if there are actual connections across upgrade then it would cause a problem.

The other option is that I can modify the reload() semantics to look at the new volume_export entities, which will be empty on upgrade to enforce the re-export of volumes.

[~neil], let's talk about this tomorrow.

Note that the cleanup stuff is NOT in eucalyptus_storage/Volumes.  This should be eucalyptus_storage/iscsivolumeinfo, correct?

We're still seeing this behaviour on various clouds.  Attached to SUP-262 is iscsivolumeinfo_output.txt, [~neil], [~zhill], what does it need to look like to resolve this issue?  Once the SC is restarted it cleans up but its not actually releasing the loopbacks on detach.  Can I presume cleanup needs to be "t" and what are the implications of changing this value on all volumes marked as "available" (i.e. not attached).  Better yet, we're planning to ensure all volumes are detached during a maintenance period and at that point we could set the flag on all volumes in the system.

A big +1 on the need to resolve this and make sure we cater for this condition between 3.2 > 3.3.
Yes, clean up should be "t" When that is done for volumes that are not attached, the SC will attempt to periodically scan and unexport those.
Thanks, we'll make note of this in regards to current deployments.

Fixed via workaround and method to release loopbacks.  Programmatic fix could lose data, which is possible to resolve completely, but not without a large effort.  If we want this resolved, it should become a feature request and put into the queue for 3.4
